title.children: Hamas warns it will kill hostages every time Israel strikes as Netanyahu says offensive has 'only started'

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: NSW Premier Chris Minns says he was horrified by the protest at the Sydney Opera House last night. "To celebrate what's happened in the Middle East in the last 48 hours is abhorrent," he told ABC News Breakfast. "I can't understand why the protest went ahead in any event. "The position of the New South Wales government is unambiguously clear — we lit up the Opera House in solidarity with the people of Israel and the Jewish community in New South Wales because we were as horrified as the rest of the community at the indiscriminate slaughter that took place in Israel." He said the situation was "obviously intolerable" for the Jewish community of New South Wales. "We cannot have a situation where members of the Jewish community feel that they can't and are being told not to participate in their city," he said. He said the decision to tell members of the Jewish community not to go to the Opera House was an "operational policing decision for the safety and security of the city". He said there were discussions happening between the government, police and the Jewish community. "The situation where they're told not to come into the city, despite it being an operational decision in a tight time frame, went ahead last night but that's intolerable for the future, and I know New South Wales police are talking with that community today and changes will be made." Watch the full interview below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Minns says he 'can't understand' why protest at Sydney Opera House went ahead

children.content: NSW Premier Chris Minns says he was horrified by the protest at the Sydney Opera House last night.
"To celebrate what's happened in the Middle East in the last 48 hours is abhorrent," he told ABC News Breakfast.
"I can't understand why the protest went ahead in any event.

"The position of the New South Wales government is unambiguously clear — we lit up the Opera House in solidarity with the people of Israel and the Jewish community in New South Wales because we were as horrified as the rest of the community at the indiscriminate slaughter that took place in Israel."
He said the situation was "obviously intolerable" for the Jewish community of New South Wales.
"We cannot have a situation where members of the Jewish community feel that they can't and are being told not to participate in their city," he said.
He said the decision to tell members of the Jewish community not to go to the Opera House was an "operational policing decision for the safety and security of the city".
He said there were discussions happening between the government, police and the Jewish community.
"The situation where they're told not to come into the city, despite it being an operational decision in a tight time frame, went ahead last night
but that's intolerable for the future, and I know New South Wales police are talking with that community today and changes will be made."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Josephine Lim Foreign Minister Penny Wong told ABC Radio Adelaide that Australia hasn't been asked to provide defence support. "What we are doing is engaging with Israelis but also, as per their request, with others in the region because what we don’t want to see is this escalate any further," she said, adding she spoke with the Jordanian foreign minister last night. Responding to criticisms that her statement yesterday was a "half-hearted response", Ms Wong said she "unequivocally" condemned the Hamas attack and called for the protection of civilian lives. "I would have thought that was a pretty unremarkable thing for Australia to call for, we always seek that as a nation, we always called for civilian lives to be protected," she said. "My response would be, what would the alternative be? "Australia calls for hostages to be returned. We condemn Hamas's abhorrent attacks. We stand with Israel and we recognise its rights to defend itself."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Wong says she 'unequivocally' condemns Hamas attack after criticism of 'half-hearted' response

children.content: Foreign Minister Penny Wong told ABC Radio Adelaide that Australia hasn't been asked to provide defence support.

"What we are doing is engaging with Israelis but also, as per their request, with others in the region because what we don’t want to see is this escalate any further," she said, adding she spoke with the Jordanian foreign minister last night.
Responding to criticisms that her statement yesterday was a "half-hearted response", Ms Wong said she "unequivocally" condemned the Hamas attack and called for the protection of civilian lives.
"I would have thought that was a pretty unremarkable thing for Australia to call for, we always seek that as a nation, we always called for civilian lives to be protected," she said.
"My response would be, what would the alternative be?
"Australia calls for hostages to be returned. We condemn Hamas's abhorrent attacks. We stand with Israel and we recognise its rights to defend itself."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: After Hamas gunmen invaded Israel's villages, videos began to emerge of seized Israelis being dragged away into Gaza. One showed an elderly woman, a defiant expression on her face, driven on a golf cart into the Palestinian enclave. Her granddaughter Adva Adar recognised her grandmother Yafa instantly. In one video, Yafa appears to be surrounded by two armed men and a driver. In another, there's a man next to her in the back seat and the driver is laughing. "I can't even start to understand how people think it makes sense to kidnap an 85-year-old lady," Adva says, "It is an animal action, it is not human." Adva says her family does not know how long her grandmother can live without her medicine. "I do know that every minute she doesn't have her medicine she is in a lot of pain and she is suffering," she says. "I am sure she is feeling very scared and I'm sure she feels very alone, and that's not a way to live when you are 85." Watch Adva speak about her grandmother below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Granddaughter says taking 85yo woman hostage is 'not human'

children.content: After Hamas gunmen invaded Israel's villages, videos began to emerge of seized Israelis being dragged away into Gaza.
One showed an elderly woman, a defiant expression on her face, driven on a golf cart into the Palestinian enclave.
Her granddaughter Adva Adar recognised her grandmother Yafa instantly.
In one video, Yafa appears to be surrounded by two armed men and a driver. In another, there's a man next to her in the back seat and the driver is laughing.
"I can't even start to understand how people think it makes sense to kidnap an 85-year-old lady," Adva says,
"It is an animal action, it is not human."
Adva says her family does not know how long her grandmother can live without her medicine.
"I do know that every minute she doesn't have her medicine she is in a lot of pain and she is suffering," she says.
"I am sure she is feeling very scared and I'm sure she feels very alone, and that's not a way to live when you are 85."
Watch Adva speak about her grandmother below.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Kimberley Price Collingwood captain Darcy Moore has come out in support of the Yes campaign ahead of this weekend's Voice referendum. It follows fellow sports star, Panthers NRL Premiership hero Nathan Cleary also announcing his support for a First Nations Voice to Parliament. A week after winning the AFL Premiership, Darcy Moore told RN Breakfast host Patricia Karvelas that despite what some people thought, sport and politics could mix. "I'll be voting yes. To me, I feel like it's an intuitive next step and seems to be an important and practical way to help Indigenous Australians," he said. "There are certainly people out there that want you to shut up and play sport, but we've seen all around the country, like with Nathan Cleary, athletes are human beings and citizens of the country too, so they can exercise their right and say what they want to say and they can do it in a really healthy way. "The argument around division … to my mind there is already advisory bodies for Indigenous Australians that have come and gone as governments have changed. The mechanism has kind of already existed anyway, so by making it sort of permanent in the constitution, it's just locking it in. So in that way it's not anything new." Listen to the full interview below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Collingwood captain Darcy Moore backs Yes vote on RN

featuredLink.title: 'I'll be voting Yes': Collingwood captain Darcy Moore backs the Voice - ABC listen

that despite what some people thought, sport and politics could mix.
"I'll be voting yes. To me, I feel like it's an intuitive next step and seems to be an important and practical way to help Indigenous Australians," he said.

"There are certainly people out there that want you to shut up and play sport, but we've seen all around the country, like with Nathan Cleary, athletes are human beings and citizens of the country too, so they can exercise their right and say what they want to say and they can do it in a really healthy way.

"The argument around division … to my mind there is already advisory bodies for Indigenous Australians that have come and gone as governments have changed. The mechanism has kind of already existed anyway, so by making it sort of permanent in the constitution, it's just locking it in. So in that way it's not anything new."
Listen to the full interview below.

Do you approve this change?" Click the link below for more of your Voice to Parliament questions answered.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning! We will be bringing you the latest developments on the Voice to Parliament referendum as it happens today. Yesterday, the AEC said that more than 2.2 million votes had been cast with pre-polling underway. Prime Minister Anthony Albanese rejected suggestions that the Yes vote was sunk as he campaigned around the country. United Australia Party senator Ralph Babet failed in his appeal in a last-minute Federal Court case over how ticks and crosses will be counted in the Voice referendum. Stay tuned for the latest updates as they unfold today.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Welcome to our live coverage

liveBlogPostPrepared.title: How the markets are looking at 7.30am AEDT:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning everyone, The ASX200 index is expected to rise a little on the opening bell, with the futures suggesting it will rise 0.3% after gains on Wall Street overnight. The price of brent crude oil is up 4%, to US$88 a barrel, in the wake of the outbreak of extreme violence in Israel and Gaza. The economist Claudia Goldin won the 2023 Sveriges Riksbank Prize in Economic Sciences in Memory of Alfred Nobel overnight (the ersatz Nobel Prize in economics), becoming only the third woman to do so. We'll be bringing you the latest breaking market and economic news today, so stay with us.
